title: Blackletter Type Suggestions for Branding
content:
Hi all. I’m currently in the process of branding a company (Loa Creative) and wanted to get a few suggestions on a nice, strong blackletter face that has that “feel”. I’ve been looking at a few 19th Century medicine labels (friend is a fanatical collector of them) and noticed that A LOT of them promoted themselves via blackletter faces. I was looking for a face that encompassed something archaic, but still familiar. I’m not particularly looking for legibilty, as it will be used in conjuction with symbols used in the vodoun religion (hense the name Loa). Any suggestions?? Thanks!

author: mrbixby

comments.content: Fakir is good. [FF Brokenscript](http://web.archive.org/web/20071031225848/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_brokenscript/) is also simple enough that it avoids the legibility issues with other blacketters in the modern world.
Darka, which you can see [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20071031225848/http:/typographica.org/001103.php) with links, is wild and mysterious—seems like just the ticket.
i think [Tiptoe](http://web.archive.org/web/20071031225848/http:/vllg.com/KLTF/Tiptoe/mudTyper+Weights/) has the feel of black letter, even though it’s not a black letter.

I really like Darka Will, but I want to stay within the tie genre of 19th century “side show potions”. You know the kind....”Drink this and you’ll be able to fly and have the strength of 100 elephants”...kinda thing. I really like [Black Pearl](http://web.archive.org/web/20071031225848/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontmesa/black-pearl/regular/) and also [Archive School Text](http://web.archive.org/web/20071031225848/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/archivetype/archive-school-text/archive-school-text/). Any more suggestions along these lines? I really appreciate the comments everyone!!
